column2: What is the effect of management extensification on grasslands plant diversity?
column3: grassland ecology, biodiversity research, restoration ecology
column4: Explore the range of existing hypotheses in the literature on a given question
column11: Management extensification affects grassland biodiversity. The direction of this effect depends on the grasslands ' resource availability. According to the intermediate disturbance and stress hypothesis, medium levels of management should support the highest biodiversity levels, as both competition for nutrients and light are in their best balance. So highly fertilized and cut grasslands should improve in their biodiversity die to extensification, while in abandoned grasslands increasing management to intermediate levels should be Most beneficial. Nutrient retention in soils however can lead to slow effects of extensification on highly managed and thus cut and fertilized grasslands.

column2: What is the best way to manage a 1 hectare stand of Phragmites Australis in a near-urban area?
column11: Phragmites Australis can be managed through cutting (i.e. mowing), spading, herbicide or animal grazing. Each technique has trade-offs and benefits. In a near-urban area, mowing or spading are the best categories of removal technique. Animal grazing may also be possible.

column2: How does buckthorn invasion impact biodiversity?
column11: Buckthorn forms a dense canopy that leafs out before native plants, outcompeting them for light. Buckthorn also inhibits seed germination through an allelopathic mechanism. The berries from buckthorn can be harmful to birds and other animals who eat them.
